types.desc: A topic is chosen from suggestions placed into a basket.
This meeting is focused on the needs of new members
Approved N.A. Books
This Meeting can be attended by speakers of English and another language.
This meeting is focused on discussion of the Basic Text of Narcotics Anonymous.
This meeting is closed to non-addicts. You should attend only if you believe that you may have a problem with substance abuse.
This meeting gathers in a facility that is usually closed on holidays.
This meeting is held by candlelight.
This meeting is focused on discussion of the twelve concepts
Well-behaved, supervised children are welcome.
Children are welcome at this meeting.
This meeting invites participation by all attendees.
This Meeting can be attended by speakers of English.
This meeting is conducted in Spanish.
Discussion of the Fifth Step and the Tenth Step
This meeting is focused on the needs of gay, lesbian and transgender members
Meets Virtually and In-person
This meeting is held in a facility that requires visitors to provide ID to enter.
This meeting is focused on the needs of members with chronic illness.
This meeting is focused on discussion of one or more Informational Pamphlets.
This meeting is focused on discussion of the It Works -How and Why text.
This meeting is focused on discussion of the Just For Today text.
Lithuanian/Russian Speaking Meeting
This is a discussion of the NA book Living Clean -The Journey Continues.
This meeting is focused on topics encountered by men in recovery.
This meeting encourages its participants to engage in quiet meditation.
Please do not bring children to this meeting.
Smoking is not allowed at this meeting.
This meeting is open to addicts and non-addicts alike. All are welcome.
No fixed duration. The meeting continues until everyone present has had a chance to share.
Persian speaking meeting
This meeting has a format that consists of each person who shares picking the next person.
Attendees may ask questions and expect answers from Group members.
This facility places restrictions on attendees.
This meeting has a format that changes for each meeting.
This meeting has a fixed sharing order (usually a circle.)
This meeting is held in a facility that has surveillance cameras.
This meeting is lead by a speaker, then opened for participation by attendees.
This meeting is focused on discussion of the Step Working Guide text.
This meeting provides an American Sign Language (ASL) interpreter for the deaf.
This meeting is a speaker-only meeting. Other attendees do not participate in the discussion.
This meeting is focused on discussion of the Twelve Steps.
Facility is Temporarily Closed
This meeting has sharing time limited by a timer.
This meeting is based upon a topic chosen by a speaker or by group conscience.
This meeting is focused on discussion of the Twelve Traditions.
This meeting engages in detailed discussion of one or more of the Twelve Traditions.
Meets Virtually
This meeting is focused on topics encountered by women in recovery.
This meeting is wheelchair accessible.
This is a meeting that gathers on the Internet.
This meeting is focused on the needs of younger members.
This meeting is held in a facility that requires visitors to provide ID to enter.

The book Alcoholic Anonymous (the Big Book) is the text for these meetings. When the focus is on a specific text, usually the group supplies copies of the book for attendees. If you would like to make notations in the text, obtaining a personal copy is useful. In the case of Big Books, a number of meetings in the area give new members a copy to keep for their own use. Ask around for these meetings.

This type of meeting focuses on specific material from the Big Book and the book Twelve Steps and Twelve Traditions (12 & 12). Again texts are usually supplied for attendees, but individual copies are available from Central Service.
These are chairperson led meetings focusing on the monthly publication of the Grapevine.
A chairperson leads the meeting in a discussion of material drawn from the AA publication Living Sober.
The Promises of Alcoholics Anonymous are on pages 82 and 83 of the Big Book. These are the focus of a chairperson led discussion.
A recent addition to the AA library, Reflections provides daily material for meditation and prayer. Meetings of this type focus on this daily practice.

Using the book Twelve Steps and Twelve Traditions (12 & 12) the meeting focuses on the Steps. Depending on group conscience, a new step is read and discussed each week. Alternately, participants read and discuss individual paragraphs with each week building on the prior weeks work.
The key here is the word 'enhanced'. The group's conscience mandates a specific and detailed approach to the Big Book and the 12 & 12.
The meeting focuses on both the 12 Steps and the 12 Traditions. The formats of these meetings vary. Please investigate on your own.
The second half of the 12 and 12 are the focus of these meetings.
These meetings are a combination of the Traditions and the Promises.

Any of the above meetings may, by group conscience, be designated as a Beginner meeting. These meetings are usually led by more experienced group members with the primary focus on introducing new members to the tools available for the maintenance of sobriety. Beginners are not restricted to meetings of this type; they are welcomed at all 12 Step meetings. A benefit of a 'beginner' meeting is the opportunity to meet other peers as they start their sober lives.
